transcripts.text: Again, I'm not going to comment on my discussions with the president or senior staff.
Are you aware of any conversations that have addressed that?
Again, I'm not going to comment on any specific conversations that I have with the president.
So you're not going to comment on whether the party affiliation of the mayors or governors has come up in any of your conversations with the president?
Not in mine.

Will you follow up, please, with this committee and ask your staff if they are familiar with this case?  And if that was a DHS agent.  U.S.  Marshals.  Sir, may I finish, please?  U.S.  Marshals.  And will you answer to this committee, once you have checked with your staff, if they are familiar with this incident?  And if it was one of your agents, was there any disciplinary action taken?  Do you follow up with the committee?
Just answered.

Sir, I would advise you, knowing there are women, including pregnant women, in these protests, I would advise you, knowing, and it is well known, there are mothers, including pregnant women, who are attending these protests.  I would advise you, sir, to consult with medical experts.
I'll go to Senator Harris.

Thank you, Mr.  Chairman.  Congress and this committee in particular has a responsibility, of course, to ensure that the Census Bureau completes a full and accurate 2020 census free from political interference.  Yet in the last week, the administration made clear that it is overriding Census Bureau professionals by forcing them to rush by one month remaining census operations, regardless of the quality and the accuracy of that data.  This political interference, if not checked by Congress, will harm hard-to-count communities, including rural communities, communities of color, tribal nations, and low-income communities for the next decade at least.  So, Chairman, I urge you to schedule a hearing on this topic because, of course, we have a duty to ensure a fair and accurate census.
We've already reached out, so again, we're going to probably leave session here.  I'm not sure when a hearing would be scheduled, but I've already reached out to the department.

I appreciate that.  Mr.  Secretary, on August 3rd, the Washington Post reported that you regularly talk with the president and Stephen Miller.  Have you discussed the deployment of DHS agents to protests in connection with the president's reelection effort and with the president or any of his staff, White House staff or campaign staff?

Again, I'm not going to comment on my discussions with the president or senior staff.  All the events that have taken place in Portland or the events as it relates Sir, have you discussed the deployments with any of his campaign staff?
No.
Have all been at the direction of the department.
I'm not sure if I heard your answer.  Have you discussed the deployments with any of the president's campaign staff?
No.
And has the party affiliation of particular mayors or governors come up in any of your conversations with anyone about the deployments?
Not in my conversations.
Are you aware of any conversations that have addressed that?
Again, I'm not going to comment on any specific conversations that I have with the president.
So you're not going to comment on whether the party affiliation of the mayors or governors has come up in any of your conversations with the president?

Not in mine.  I've just, sorry, general statement, because I see where you're going, is I'm not going to comment specifically on any discussions that I've had with the president or senior staff.  What I can tell you is our deployment of law enforcement officers to Portland or in support of Operation Legend are done within DHS authorities and not for any political specific reasons.

On July 23rd, a United States Federal District Court judge ordered DHS and U.S.  Marshals to stop arresting, threatening, or using force against journalists and legal observers.  I'm assuming that you were aware of that ruling on the day it came down.
